The law of conservation of energy can be derived in any field theory of physics using Noether's theorem which says that it follows from the fact that the laws of physics do not change with time. Amazingly some cosmologists have become confused by the fact that the universe is expanding so that they think Noether's theorem does not apply. This is wrong. Noether's theorem only requires that the equations of the theory are unchanging, not the solution. The universe may change as it expands but the way in which it expands is the solution to equations that do not change with time.

The first formulation for energy conservation in cosmology was given by Einstein in 1916 shortly after formulating the theory of general relativity. Other formulations have been written into well-known textbooks including those by Landau and Lifshitz, Dirac and Weinberg. All these formulations for energy are equivalent. They can also be found in Wikipedia under pseudo-tensors. For people who don't like pseudotensors there is a covariant formulation due to Komar. There is no excuse for anyone who works with general relativity not to understand how the law of conservation of energy works in cosmology.

The equation for energy in the standard cosmological models for an expanding universe including radiation and dark energy as well as ordinary matter can be derived from these formulations and is as follows:

E= Mc^2 + Γ/a + (Λc^2/κ)a^3 − (3/κ)a˙^2a − Ka (= 0?)

E is the total energy in an expanding region of volume a(t)^3.This always comes to zero in a perfectly homogeneous cosmology.

a(t) is the universal expansion factor as a function of time normalised to 1 at the current epoch. It started as zero and increases with time as the universe gets bigger.

a˙ is the derivative of a(t) with respect to time, in other words it is the rate of expansion of the universe.

M is the total mass (momentum) of matter in the region

c is the speed of light

Γ is the density of cosmic radiation normalised to the current epoch

Λ is the cosmological constant also known as dark energy, thought to be positive.

κ is the gravitational coupling constant. In terms of Newton's gravitational constant G it is κ=8πG/c^2

K is a constant that is positive for spherical closed space, negative for hyperbolic space and zero for flat space.

This equation tells us that the positive energy in matter, radiation and dark energy is perfectly balanced by a negative quantity of energy in the gravitational field that depends on the rate of expansion of the universe. As the universe expands the length scale a(t) increases. The amount of energy in ordinary matter Mc^2 is constant in an expanding volume. The radiation energy Γ/a decreases due to cosmic redshift and the amount of dark energy  (Λc^2/κ)a^3 increases as the volume expands. The rate of expansion must adjust (that is, if the energy comes to a total of zero. But we don't know yet what the total energy of the universe is or whether it is even a constant. At best, we can look at the current evidence, which all points towards the universe likely being very flat with a total energy of zero. But who knows? Further details and simple explanations can be found at pbs spacetime) so that the negative gravitational energy balances the sum of these energies. If you all have trouble wrapping your heads around this, there is another way of explaining what is going on. I'm not sure if it'll be more illuminating, but let me try to explain it anyway. It is, of course, consistent with everything Dianna said, it's just a different way of putting the same physical concepts into words.
Even in non-relativistic mechanics, the energy of an object depends on the reference frame you are considering. Let's say a ball is at rest with respect to me. It's kinetic energy will then vanish. Now consider another observer, moving with respect to me with speed v. From the point of view of this observer, the kinetic energy of the ball will not vanish. Indeed, it'll be mv^2/2, where m is the ball's mass. So, it only makes sense to compare the energy of two different systems or of the same system at different instants of time if we use a single reference frame for both.
When we consider photons in an expanding Universe, something similar happens. The energy of the photon at different times is changing, but not because it's losing energy to something, but rather because we are looking at it from different reference frames. Now you might ask: why don't we fix a single reference frame once and for all and use it to study the motion of the photon at all times? Well, because we can't. This is one of the surprising facts about general relativity, that reference frames cannot, in general, be defined globally. Each reference frame can only be used to describe events in a limited region of spacetime, that is small enough for its curvature to be negligible. So, if we want to study a photon that has been travelling for billions of years, we actually have to choose a different reference frame to look at it at each instant of time. Since the reference frame is changing, the numerical value of the energy is changing. This shouldn't be more mysterious than the example of the ball that I gave first. In particular, I hope it's clear that it makes no sense to speculate about "where the photon energy is going". It isn't going anywhere. If, from the point of view of a single reference frame, the energy of an object diminishes with time, then OK, some other physical entity must be receiving this energy. But this is not what is going on with the photon. The energy changes because the reference frame changes, that's all.

I don't think it is accurate to call this a violation of Conservation of Energy. Ethan Siegel at Stars With A Bang wrote a piece on medium last year attempting to address the exact same question (Where does the energy of photons red shifted by the cosmic expansion go?"), and his conclusion was that, at best, this MIGHT present a violation of CoE in some future quantum theory of gravity; but given our present understanding of physics, it is completely consistent with Conservation of Energy:

"[...] as the Universe expands, photons lose energy. But that doesn’t mean energy isn’t conserved; it means that the energy goes into the Universe’s expansion itself, in the form of work. And if the Universe ever reverses the expansion and contracts again, that work will be done in reverse, and will go right back into the photons inside. It is possible that in a fuller (i.e., quantum) theory of gravity, a stricter definition of energy will emerge, and we’ll be able to truly see whether it is or isn’t conserved. But in the absence of a strict definition, all we can do is use what we have to work with, and those are the tools and definitions we already have. Yes, photons lose energy, but that energy doesn’t disappear forever; the amount of energy loss (or gain, for that matter) adds up to exactly what it should in the expanding (or contracting) Universe."

Source: https://medium.com/starts-with-a-bang/ask-ethan-when-a-photon-gets-redshifted-where-does-the-energy-go-9b97d9b49d5c#.z2cmabo73
